302.76.text:
DS: I feel I was one of the very fortunate
Canadians to have known June Callwood, and

310.35.text:
of course, I, like millions of Canadians across
the country were grateful to have a person

315.82.text:
like that who I thought was the best example
of what civil society and leadership is all

321.78.text:
about and how we miss her, especially in these
trying times with the government that we've

329.58.text:
got. I don't mean Ontario, I mean the federal
government.

336.06.text:
DS: And looking at or listening to the recitation
of the people that have been part of this

342.81.text:
wonderful lecture series, I feel very honoured
to be here with you tonight. My grandparents

351.56.text:
emigrated to Canada from Japan between 1902
and 1906. My parents were born in Vancouver,

360.28.text:
dad in 1909 and my mom in 1911. My grandparents
never learned to speak English and my parents

371.93.text:
said, "You're Canadians to me and you're gonna
learn to speak English well and if you're

378.04.text:
gonna learn another language it's gotta be
French." So I never learned to speak Japanese

383.88.text:
and what it meant was that I never had a conversation,
a serious conversation with any of my grandparents.

389.72.text:
DS: And I never got to ask when my last grandmother
died I realized that the whole part of who

396.59.text:
I am was gone, I didn't know why they came
to Canada, how difficult it was to make that

402.98.text:
four to six week journey across the pacific
and what did they find when they came to a

408.09.text:
very hostile country. Were they happy or glad
that they came and stayed? And how did they

415.52.text:
feel about... I never got to ask these important
questions. And now that I'm an elder, I'm

422.09.text:
in the last part of my life and I know that
I could kick the bucket at any moment. And

428.12.text:
when I do I don't want my grandchildren to
go, "Oh gosh! I wish I'd asked that about

435.18.text:
grandpa", or 'Bompa' as my grandchildren call
me. The book by the way is not 'Letters To

441.65.text:
My Children', it's 'Letters To My Grandchildren',
yes.

445.65.text:
DS: So, this is why I wrote the letter and
it really, the book, it's a conversation with

454.31.text:
my grandchildren. So you know, in any conversation
you start along on a certain topic and you

458.61.text:
suddenly loop out into something else and
then come back into it. That's how I tried

463.64.text:
to develop the book and in the past, when
I've had a book tour I've just used the book

470.71.text:
as an excuse to give a speech about the environment
and I just give a talk.

475.98.text:
DS: But this is a very different kind of book
and I wanted to share some of the ideas and

481.07.text:
messages that I was trying to pass on to my
grandchildren. So, this is a book written

487.62.text:
for my grandchildren but I hope for those
of you that may buy it and read it that as

492.69.text:
you read it, you will consider what you want
to tell your grandchildren and pass on to

500.36.text:
them. I meant to put up a diagram of my family.
I had, I contributed to the population problem.

510.76.text:
DS: I have five children, three from my first
marriage and from them, I have three grandchildren

515.77.text:
from two of my daughters. One set are Tamo
and Midori and their father was a Chilean,

524.94.text:
and Jonathan lives in Toronto with his mom
and dad and he has severe cerebral palsy,

531.96.text:
so he's got very special needs. My second
wife Tara and I had two daughters, Severn

537.90.text:
and Sarika and they've got... Severn is married
to a Haida, lives in Haida Gwaii and they

545.41.text:
have two sons. Ganhlaans, we call him Ghani
and Tiisaan and recently my youngest daughter

553.99.text:
just completed her PhD and completed at the
same time she gave birth to my last grandson

560.29.text:
Ryo. Ryo, they chose the word because in Spanish
it means river. Chris, the father is a river

567.80.text:
guide, and Ryo because in Japanese it means
dragon.

572.43.text:
DS: So, let me start then on the book. We
often speak of Canada as if it is founded

580.89.text:
on the two original countries from France
and from England and that's the basis of what

587.87.text:
this country is. And I think this really overlooks
the fact that there is a much more fundamental

595.80.text:
difference between the indigenous people who
were here when Europeans first came. And then

602.44.text:
all of the migrants who have come here over
the past 500 years. There's a fundamental

608.33.text:
difference in perspective that really explains
a lot of things about why we've been so ecologically

615.12.text:
destructive but also why indigenous people
now are really leading the fight about the

622.03.text:
environment. So let me start with a passage
here. "My mother and father, like most of

632.43.text:
the Japanese kids born in Canada at that time
grew up without elders or grandparents because

640.31.text: they were all back in Japan."

642.57.text:
DS: "Can you imagine growing up without ever
knowing your grandparents? This lack of grandparents

650.62.text:
and other elders, I believe was significant
for children of immigrants to all new and

656.73.text:
distant lands, not just Canada. Because it
meant that they had only the shallowest roots

663.88.text:
to the old country and no roots at all in
the new one. Although, there was anti-Asian

671.81.text:
racism and discrimination, Canada offered
opportunities that Japan didn't. And when

679.86.text:
the Japanese arrived in Canada, they did not
have the historical or cultural attachment

686.43.text:
to the land that indigenous people have. And
so what they saw land as was as a commodity,

694.87.text:
real-estate. If there were fish on it, catch
them and sell them. If there are trees, cut

699.71.text:
them down and sell them. If there were minerals,
dig them up and sell them. If there was topsoil,

705.07.text:
grow vegetables and sell them. That's why
people sought new lands.

711.11.text:
DS: For resources to exploit for economic
return. And that's the way it's been for immigrants

718.92.text:
ever since that great wave of exploration,
conquest, and settlement in North and South

725.49.text:
America, Africa, Australia and New Zealand
that began five centuries ago. As you know...

733.36.text:
" So this is, I'm writing to my children,
grandchildren, "Nana", that's my wife Tara,

737.77.text:
"Nana and I have worked a lot with First Nations
people in Canada, and with other indigenous

743.17.text:
communities in other parts of the world. We
have learned so much from them about radically

749.19.text:
different ways of seeing the land. For people
who lived in an area for thousands of years

757.46.text:
rather than mere decades or even centuries,
land is far more than a commodity. It is their

764.51.text:
home, and it is sacred." And that I think
is the lesson that we're gaining as more and

770.77.text:
more aboriginal people are involved in the
environmental battles going on.

776.74.text:
DS: People often ask me, especially young
people, what it was that led me on the career

782.99.text:
path that ultimately led to environmental
activism, and I tell them that one of the

791.59.text:
major factors that shaped the direction I
took as a person was Pearl Harbour. When Japan

798.82.text:
attacked the United States in 1941 it turned
the lives of Japanese-Canadians like me and

805.82.text:
my family upside down, and the consequences
of that, the loss of our property, incarceration

813.16.text:
for three years and then expulsion from BC,
the consequences of that led to many of my

820.16.text:
hang-ups, and I've got lots and a knee-jerk
response to bigots and discrimination. So

829.60.text:
let me read from the first chapter on racism.
"My dearest grandchildren, you are growing

836.75.text:
up in a very different time from when I was
a boy. Even though I was a Canadian, born

842.27.text:
in Canada like my mum and dad, we were suspect
because we were of Japanese descent.

848.53.text:
DS: Equality before the law, freedom of speech
and movement, the right to vote, are principles

855.13.text:
of democracy that you all take for granted,
but they did not always apply to everyone.

861.33.text:
Ganhi and Tiisaan, you know your nannai and
chinnai's parents, nannai and chinnai are

867.12.text:
grandparents in Haida, couldn't vote because
they were Haida, and my parents couldn't vote

873.29.text:
either because they were Japanese. It's important
to remember that, and to understand that today

880.11.text:
you might not feel discriminated against,
but the bigots who hate Muslims, Jews, gays

886.63.text:
or any other group because of colour, religion,
ethnic group, sexual orientation or even poverty

893.92.text:
could just as easily turn against you because
they are ignorant and in their ignorance are

900.00.text:
afraid of people who look different or act
differently, behave differently.

905.43.text:
DS: We must always stick up for someone who
is being picked on because one day it could

911.74.text:
be our turn again. Its funny how when we were
kids we don't see the differences that adults

918.63.text:
do. We learn what to fear or hate from our
parents or others around us. When I was a

925.08.text:
boy we were living in a small town in Leamington,
Ontario. A friend and I were playing in an

931.02.text:
empty lot one day when dad came by on his...
Coming from work on his bike. I yelled to

936.41.text:
him and he waved back, and my friend just
looked at me with these big wide eyes and

942.05.text: he said, "How do you know him?"

945.34.text:
DS: I laughed and said, "That was my dad,
stupid."

950.21.text:
DS: "But he's a chink," my friend said, and
I didn't know whether to laugh or to be angry

957.36.text:
because he had used a racial slur, but I realized
that when we played together colour made no

963.84.text:
difference, yet he could see racial differences
as he recognized in dad, and he must have

970.03.text: been told something bad about chinks. I...

979.00.text:
DS: So I have a chapter called Motivation
and Values. "My father was my great mentor,

988.77.text:
my teacher, my hero, and in 1994 he was dying,
and I moved in to care for him the last month

996.43.text:
of his life, that was one of the most wonderful
times I had with my father. He wasn't in pain,

1002.96.text:
he knew he was dying, he wasn't afraid, and
dad had always been terrible with his money.

1008.43.text:
He just had... If he had it he spent it, and
it was mum who managed the money, and Tara

1013.93.text:
and I had supported them for years, and yet
as I cared for him he kept saying, "David,

1021.07.text:
I die a rich man." We talked, we laughed,
we cried, but he never once said, "You remember

1029.77.text:
that wonderful house we had in London, Ontario?"
He never said, "I had a fine closet full of

1037.23.text:
clothes," or "Remember that car in 1986 that
I bought?". All we talked about were family,

1044.16.text:
friends and neighbours, and things that we
did together.

1047.13.text:
DS: That's what my dad wanted to remember
at the end of his life, and to him that was

1053.97.text:
his wealth and in those he was truly a rich
man. "As I watch you grow older Tamo, as the

1064.67.text:
eldest of my grandchildren, your incredible
athleticism in hockey, football and snowboarding

1071.58.text:
seemed to be leading you to some kind of career
in sports. I was so surprised and so proud

1078.39.text:
when you morphed into a snowboard activist
trying to entice young boarders to notice

1084.62.text:
the world around them and how they were affected
by it and how they could make it better. Because

1090.43.text:
of your Chilean roots, you could snowboard
in Canada during the winter and then continue

1095.93.text:
snowboarding in Chile during the summer. As
a result you were exposed to issues of poverty

1102.76.text:
in South America, and to environmental concerns
like the plight of sea turtles. And you have

1108.64.text: since gone on to become an environmental activist."

1111.83.text:
DS: "I wonder where that will lead you in
the coming years, but go for it, I'm with

1117.46.text:
you. Young people often ask me, 'How can I
save the world?' And I tell them, 'Don't worry

1125.05.text:
about the world, the planet will do fine with
or without us.' But I tell them, 'Follow your

1131.74.text:
heart. Do what you love, whether it's art,
music, writing, fixing cars or carpentry.'

1138.79.text:
Environmentalism, you see, is not a specialty
or a discipline like medicine or teaching

1146.03.text:
or law. It's a way of seeing the world and
recognizing that we are a part of the biosphere,

1155.10.text:
dependent on nature, air, water, soil, photosynthesis,
biodiversity, for our health and well being.

1164.77.text:
And we need everyone to see the world through
that lens". In a chapter called 'My life in

1173.99.text:
Media', I write about some of the experiences
and observations. And I've been urging for

1182.62.text:
years, young people to get outside and experience
nature.

1186.18.text:
DS: So it's really disturbed me that people
are really intrigued with all of this electronic

1191.54.text:
stuff that's going on, and the cyber world.
You know, you can get glasses now and have

1196.79.text:
whole scenes going on in a helmet, you don't
have to go out in the real world. And the

1201.50.text:
problem for me is that the cyber world in
many ways can be better than the real world.

1207.62.text:
I mean, you can actually have a gun fight
in a cyber world, die, and live to fight again.

1216.27.text:
You can go in a race car and drive with all
of the adrenaline, heart-thumping excitement

1223.20.text:
of the experience, crash, and walk away. You
can have the kinkiest sex and not have to

1228.65.text:
worry about STDs or getting caught. The cyber
world can be better than the real world. But

1235.80.text:
I think we've got to remember that there is
another world that keeps us alive. And I had

1243.97.text:
always thought that the nature of things was
different.

1246.27.text:
DS: We present pictures of nature and get
people to see how nature is, and fall in love

1252.29.text:
with it. And now that I've thought about it,
I think, "Oh, really?" And the reason for

1260.18.text:
that is I had always thought that our programs
on 'The Nature of Things', on the program,

1267.67.text:
we were offering a picture of nature that
would seduce people into loving the real world

1273.48.text:
that we share with other species. But on reflection,
I realized we were creating images of nature

1281.12.text:
that were better than the real world. We send
wildlife filmmakers to remote places like

1287.47.text:
the Arctic or the Amazon, where they spend
weeks and months trying to get the best shots.

1294.68.text:
Polar bears emerging from a den, capturing
seals or swimming from one ice floe to the

1301.15.text:
next. Or flocks of parrots, capybaras, snakes
and jaguars in the Amazon. Then, one breathtaking

1308.93.text: shot after another is edited down...

1312.59.text:
DS: Sorry... Is edited together so that months
of effort are boiled down to a few minutes

1320.73.text:
of action. Technology also provides images
of nature not possible to see in real time

1328.37.text:
with the naked eye. Microscopy, time lapse,
high definition drones, submarines, endoscopes.

1335.53.text:
The list of technological innovations for
filming is incredible. But anyone expecting

1342.30.text:
to visit the Arctic or the Amazon to witness
the hyperactivity seen on The Nature of Things,

1349.61.text:
is going to be disappointed. In the Amazon
rainforest, much of the activity takes place

1357.26.text:
at night, or in the canopy high above the
forest floor. Nature needs time to reveal

1365.05.text:
her secrets, but we have become an impatient
animal. In a world where satellite dishes

1373.89.text:
and cable deliver dozens of channels from
which to choose, my shows have to compete

1381.02.text:
for the attention of remote control clutching
viewers who have the attention span of a hummingbird.

1388.96.text:
DS: We don't have the luxury of time to relish
the gradual revelations in nature. And the

1396.75.text:
impression we get from films and TV is of
nature hopped up on steroids. Still, as long

1404.38.text:
as we realize that the vital ingredient of
time is left out, I believe that natural history

1411.39.text:
films convey a sense of wonder, amazement
and love that we desperately need if we are

1418.65.text:
to appreciate the role that nature plays in
our lives. And... I started as the host of

1432.37.text:
'The Science Magazine' in 1974, and this was
a big deal for me. It was my first big budget

1440.96.text:
film that was going national. And it was coming
out of Toronto, but I was at the very, still

1447.66.text:
at that time, I was a full professor with
a big research lab in genetics, and quite

1454.28.text:
frankly, the genetics was much more interesting
to me than the television.

1458.00.text:
DS: I had to take a leave of absence from
the University of British Columbia to do the

1463.17.text:
series but I found that the process was very,
very tedious, and in my very first season

1473.75.text:
I gained one of the most important lessons
from my television experience. One of the

1480.74.text:
earliest shoots for Science Magazine was a
trip to New Orleans to film in a lab. I was

1489.47.text:
seated on a stool, as the camera assistant
brought in the camera and tripod and set it

1494.51.text:
up, the cameraman then said about making the
lab look like a lab, which always makes me

1501.83.text:
chuckle; apparently an actual working lab
that doesn't have test tubes bubbling with

1507.03.text:
coloured water doesn't really look like a
real lab, at least for a television audience.

1513.80.text:
DS: So as the lab was being rearranged, the
sound man put a wire down my shirt, arranged

1519.62.text:
the microphone, then asked me to say a few
words so he could adjust his recorder. A lighting

1524.35.text:
man came in and began to set up lights that
didn't show in the shot and then adjusted

1528.68.text:
the filters and the focus of the light as
the cameraman directed. Finally, when all

1534.10.text:
seemed right, the cameraman came up and put
a light meter beside my nose, to take a reading

1541.50.text:
and then went back to the camera and adjusted
the focus. Then he came back, took another

1548.58.text:
cam reading on his light meter, went back
and adjusted the focus. Nothing had changed.

1555.55.text:
DS: He did it for a third time and then a
fourth and a fifth time. So finally I said,

1562.04.text: "For Christ sakes, Rudy, shoot the damn thing!"

1565.61.text:
DS: Jim Murray, who was my boss at the time
grabbed me by the shoulder, pulled me into

1571.41.text:
a side room, slammed the door and said, "Listen
Suzuki, everyone in that room is busting their

1577.95.text: ass to make you look good and that's not easy."

1582.61.text:
DS: And I slunk back into the room, feeling
very ashamed and never, ever got up on my

1591.15.text:
high horse like that again. You see, he was
absolutely right. When a program is broadcast,

1598.50.text:
viewers like you don't say, "Wow! Every shot
was in focus".

1604.53.text:
DS: You don't say, "Wasn't the lighting great?"
Or "The sound was so crisp." What you say

1611.24.text:
is, "Wasn't Suzuki's show great?" I get all
the credit for what is the work of literally

1617.97.text:
dozens of people, from researchers, writers
and secretaries to editors, publicists and

1623.96.text:
a host of others working to make programs
and get them to air. And I feel that way about

1630.80.text:
everything I've done, from research in which
students, post-docs and colleagues all contribute

1638.54.text:
to the work that comes out in books that I've
written and co-written and my work at the

1643.62.text:
David Suzuki Foundation with its dozens of
staff, hundreds of volunteers and thousands

1650.42.text:
of donors. I get an inordinate amount of credit
for what is the result of the passion, commitment

1657.85.text:
and hard work of so many others. I feel an
enormous responsibility to them because...

1665.16.text:
Which is to do the very best I can in whatever
I'm involved in and to be as credible and

1671.61.text: true to what I say as I can.

1675.64.text:
DS: I have another segment here from a chapter
I call "Fame and Heroes". Some of you may

1687.54.text:
remember that back in the 1900s, doesn't that
sound like an ancient time now?

1692.96.text:
DS: I think it was 1968 actually that an artist
named Andy Warhol predicted that there will

1700.16.text:
come a time when everyone on earth will be
famous for 15 minutes and I think we are almost

1706.35.text:
there. Of course, this is a time when you
have YouTube and blogs and Facebook and viral

1712.87.text:
videos but it makes you ask, "What the hell
does it mean to be famous?" I thought about

1719.61.text:
this when one of my grandsons said "Bompa,

Think if we had done it. The reality is we

2136.82.text:

DS: We already know from what the Inuit tell

2174.41.text:
other country. And then you think about the

2181.77.text:

2189.11.text:

2194.79.text:
has done is wilful blindness, deliberately

2201.92.text:
a different kind of agenda. Canadians ought

2205.92.text:
DS: But in the discussions I've had over the

2211.68.text:
I'm told over and over again by politicians

realistic. These targets you're asking for

difficult." Or they say, "It can't be done,"

2237.74.text:
I spent eight years in the United States getting

2243.25.text:
at that time. I was beginning my last year

Union had launched a satellite into space.
It was sensational, I hadn't even known there

2278.47.text:
DS: This was during the Cold War and the Soviets

2283.84.text:
governments in South America and Africa. For
the Americans, every hour and a half, the

2297.66.text:

2303.71.text:

2311.51.text:
first after another. The first animal, a dog,

2327.23.text:
very advanced in science, engineering and

DS: Americans didn't shrink from the challenge,
they didn't moan about the Soviets' great

2337.59.text:
lead or object to the cost of catching up.

2345.10.text:
forming NASA, the National Aeronautics and

2351.61.text:
science departments and universities, supporting
students in science. It was a glorious time,

2358.47.text:
even for a foreign student, like me. All you
had to do was say, "I like science," and they

DS: And, on May 25th, 1961, President John

2376.04.text:

2384.16.text:
in what was now called the "space race." It
was an audacious goal, since it was far from

2391.53.text:
clear how or whether the United States could
do it, but they made the commitment to try.

2399.84.text:
And on July 20th, 1969, American astronaut,
Neil Armstrong, set foot on the moon, the

2407.04.text:
first human being, human landing there. It
was an astounding achievement, because it

2413.03.text:
was accomplished in less than a decade, and
because the United States was the first, and

2418.76.text:
so far only, country to land people on the

2426.16.text: the unexpected benefits of the space race.

2430.38.text:
DS: Since 1976, NASA has published a magazine

2440.40.text:

2454.96.text:
and ear thermometers. And Americans still

2462.49.text:
Prize winners are announced. All because in

2470.01.text:
to catch up and pass the Soviet Union in space.
So, I tell my American friends, "It's un-American

2478.50.text:
to say meeting the challenge of climate change

2486.01.text:
DS: The American I knew and admire, would

2493.12.text:
it in the full knowledge that enormous unpredictable

2501.30.text:
most important thing in meeting any challenge

2510.91.text:
book with a separate letter to each of my

2518.14.text:
DS: "Dear Tamo, my first grandchild. I'm so
proud that you recently participated in the

2527.33.text:
protest against the Kinder Morgan pipeline
in British Columbia. You did what I would

2532.68.text:
have done myself, were it not a risk to my
position as host of 'The Nature of Things.'

2539.49.text:
DS: After you were arrested and later cleared
of all charges for civil disobedience, your

2546.27.text:
mom asked me to write a letter of support
to a judge. It was never used but here is

2552.28.text:
the gist of what I wrote: "The world is on
a collision course with the things that keep

2558.12.text:
us alive and healthy, the air, water, soil
and variety of life. Corporations, especially

2566.62.text:
those with head offices in other parts of
the country or the world, care little for

2572.10.text:
the interests of local ecosystems or local
communities. Except in so far as they interfere

2578.72.text:
with the drive to maximize profit for shareholders.

2586.21.text:
or communities. Their sole goal is to make
as much money as they can get away with. Tamo

2594.53.text:
is fighting for the world that will be left
to him and his generation in the future.

2600.46.text:
DS: I believe that what Kinder Morgan and
companies like it are doing, is what his aunt

2606.71.text:

But there are no legal precedence to pursue

2612.92.text:
criminal charges on that basis. Before corporations

2621.79.text:
to leave a better future for their children.
This is not on the corporate agenda. There

2628.66.text:
are few legal avenues to protest what I believe
is the criminal activity of corporations like

2634.36.text:
Kinder Morgan. So citizens like Tamo are being
forced to participate in civil disobedience.

2642.10.text:
He is taking an active role in the struggle
for human rights, social justice and environmental

2647.49.text:
protection and he has done this without attempting

2655.12.text:
is a role model for young people today." I
only have one granddaughter. How I miss...

2663.76.text:
DS: You know, girls always love their dads

2670.23.text:

2684.74.text:
A working mother was a sign of poverty. As

2691.83.text:
demanding equal opportunity and equal pay

2696.95.text:

2705.25.text:

2712.16.text:
in these fields. More than half of all students

and law in Canada are now women. And in traditionally

2727.62.text:
and forestry, enrolment of women is rising

DS: And although there remain barriers to

they are bound to be broken by the sheer numbers

You may find it hard to believe, but Nana",

citizenship because she wanted to keep her
last name when we married. Nana was born in

to take out Canadian citizenship until we

2771.94.text:
a four month trip around the world. She needed
a passport and realized she had to take out

2778.84.text:
citizenship in order to get one. This should

2784.50.text:
she was rejected. Though her brother Peter,

DS: She appealed for reconsideration and was

finally granted citizenship and a Canadian

her last name after marriage is no big deal.

2820.20.text:
Your mother and grandmothers were feminists

2827.09.text:
their futures". Jonathan is a teenager and
he, as I said has cerebral palsy. And wow,

2841.29.text:
that is challenging. "Jonathan, you won't

2847.43.text:
parents read everything they could about the

2852.79.text:
possible to stimulate your muscles and your

2858.79.text:
flip you around, lifting you and stimulating

2864.08.text:
DS: Your parents knew that even though you

2870.09.text:
signals from other parts of the visual system.
And as a result you can read. And I don't

2879.36.text:
understand how it works but I know you look

2885.79.text:
lets you see from a different part of your

a godsend to you and you have done so well

2897.46.text:
Do you remember that summer when you came

2902.58.text:
you caught your first shiner on the dock?
How you loved the feeling of speed in our

2907.92.text:
boat as the wind blew through your hair and

2917.50.text:
sea food, the fish and prawns and clams and

2927.51.text:
their lives to the reality of your special

2932.81.text:
and filled with admiration, they're ordinary

2938.91.text: and love, which to me is truly heroic.

2942.01.text:
DS: I believe we define ourselves as a species

2949.24.text:
handicapped or in need of special care, and

2955.68.text:
species. Soon you will be finished with school

2961.57.text:
when you consider finding a house that you

2967.99.text:
challenge for you has brought great joy as

2973.34.text:
Johnathan, and Nana and I are so proud of
you. Ganhlaans is now going on seven. The

2982.90.text:
word Ganhlaans is a Haida word meaning 'people
who stand together'. "In 1981, we did a film

2991.63.text:
for The Nature of Things about the battle
over logging on Haida Gwaii and it garnered

2997.05.text:
a huge audience and letters and phone calls
supporting the Haida poured in.

3003.05.text:
DS: The way the Haida stood up to the forest
company and the government to fight for the

3008.12.text:
protection of their land inspired people all
across Canada. At the time I didn't think

3014.58.text:
the Haida had a chance against all the forces

3021.36.text:
and all the elders who are now gone, stood
together and put their bodies on the line,

3026.91.text:
on Lyell Island. They were arrested by the
dozens but their act prevented logging and

3033.39.text:
eventually resulted in the creation of Gwaii

3039.62.text:
huge achievement that inspired a nation. Ever
since Nana and I have loved to visit and when

3046.73.text:
we meet friends there, they tell us, "Welcome
home". We feel Haida Gwaii is our second home

3054.08.text:
and now that you and Tiisaan live there we
have all the more incentive to visit often.

3059.65.text:
DS: The Haida connection to the land has inspired
me and also taught me about our relationship

3066.04.text:
with mother earth. It was Guujaaw who explained

3073.34.text:
and we become like everyone else. Your nannai",
his Haida grandmother, "recognized something

3081.19.text:
in your mother when she was just a child,
and she said she wanted Severn to come to

3086.81.text:
Haida Gwaii for the summer to learn how to
live on the land. When she was young, Sev

3092.06.text:
was too shy to go but as a teenager she went
and learned so much from your nannai about

3098.69.text:
the traditional ways of food gathering and
preparation. I remember when Nana and I were

3103.70.text:
going out fishing with Miles and we met your
mother and your nannai and chinnai and Chief

3108.71.text:
Watson Price in their boat, your mother was
so happy as she showed us all the salmon she

3114.53.text:
had helped to catch and the sea urchins and
scallops she harvested, what a fantastic summer

3121.76.text:
DS: Back then, your father was a full grown
man who was chasing women already [laughter]

3128.44.text:
I am sure, your nannai never thought your
mom and dad would get together and marry one

3133.94.text:
day, but she sure was happy when they did".
And, Ganhlaans has a younger brother named

3143.52.text:
Tiisaan who's three. "You and your brother
are so loved by your parents, your grandparents

3151.11.text:
and your Haida community, and you are fortunate
to be growing up in the confidence of that

3156.20.text:
love and support, there will be times when
you are sad, lonely or upset, when you will

3162.52.text:
be able to draw on that love. My dear, sweet
Tiisaan, how Nana and I wish we could shield

3170.47.text:
you and your brother Ganhlaans from hurt that
will come during your lives. I've emphasized

3177.27.text:
the love that you are enveloped in from family,
because that is your shield, your armour against

3185.36.text:
DS: It pains me to tell you that despite the
enormous increase in appreciation and respect

3191.51.text:
for First Nations in Canada, there is still
a great deal of prejudice direct... That will

3196.81.text:
be directed at you. Some people resent what
they feel is undeserved support from their

3202.46.text:
tax dollars, on reserves, that you can pay
less in taxation or you have unwarranted claims

3210.23.text:
to the land and so on. Others point to alcoholism,

3217.41.text:
costs without regard to the historical and
social causes of many of these problems, and

3224.14.text:
as if the accusations apply to all First Nations
people. Your family will buffer you against

3231.02.text:
the pain of any encounters you will have with
people who are ignorant and don't know what

3236.25.text:
they're talking about. Know that you are a
fine human being who has the love and support

3245.56.text:
DS: And my latest grandchild is a boy named
Ryo. "As a professional rafting and kayaking

3256.51.text:
guide, your father is acutely aware of how
lucky we are to live in British Columbia.

3262.49.text:
He will regale you with wonderful stories

3269.08.text:
moose, and so many other animals in the wild.
I know he will take you on trips as soon as

3274.83.text:
you are old enough, but Chris also knows that

3280.21.text:
change, which is melting the glaciers at an
alarming rate, as well as by clear cut logging,

3286.66.text:
roads, and mining. Your mother has always
loved the ocean. As a child she would be the

3293.95.text:
first to discover or observe things. She loved
to find the smallest creatures. Crabs, sculpins,

3301.18.text:
starfish. And like your cousin Ganhlaans,

3306.64.text:
into pools or wandering beaches and forest
trails for hours, just looking and collecting.

3312.36.text:

3318.09.text:
rocks that had long antennae and one bigger
claw. She knew where to find salamanders and

3325.27.text:
had the patience to find and catch beautiful
nudibranchs. And she is the most patient and

3330.57.text:
successful fisher of all of us. So your parents
are great role models. You will grow up loving

3337.70.text:
the outdoors as you learn to kayak and canoe
with your dad, and as you accompany your mom

3342.63.text:
on field trips for her work in marine biology.
You will learn to love the ocean and rivers

3348.60.text:
and lakes, and to care about their perilous
state. And because you and your cousins love

3354.10.text:
nature, I know you will become warriors fighting
to protect the things you love". But, as an

3363.41.text:
old man I couldn't resist having a final word,
so the last chapter is called "Final Words".

3371.49.text:
DS: "My most important piece of advice to
all of you is to be thoughtful about the way

3377.56.text:
you live. At a time when the global economy
dominates our lives, its easy to buy something

3384.00.text:
without even thinking about the global repercussions
of that purchase. The ramifications of purchasing

3391.04.text:
even simple goods like clothing, food, and
drinks are immense. And when it comes to big

3397.13.text:
ticket items like a car, computer, or television
set, or even a house, the ecological, social,

3404.66.text:
and economic effects become enormous. You
see, this global system is simply too destructive

3412.49.text:
to be truly sustainable. Think about the way
we live at home. Where does the electricity

3418.55.text:
that powers our house, the water that flows
through our taps, or even the air that we

3424.41.text:
breathe come from? When we flush the toilet,
what happens to the poo, paper, pee, plastic

3432.54.text:
tampon inserts, tampons, and condoms that
